discussion.content: The answer is correct given the context of "distance limitations" mentioned in the scenario. Adding another AP is an easy solution to the issue. Common sense, really!

comments.content: users being on the other side of the building don`t get enough signal. The answer is right

discussion.content:
I think C is correct.
They mention they are using 802.11n, which WOULD use MIMO, but MIMO is about delivering faster speeds, not necessarily helping with distance, which they said is an issue.
We have no reason to think there is a channel overlap.
D. is just stupid.

questions.question_text: A network technician is assisting a SOHO environment with wireless connection issues. The business uses 802.11n and WPA2 encryption. The on-premises equipment is located toward the back of the building and includes a router, firewall, and WAP. The users at the front of the building are experiencing very slow response times due to distance limitations. Which of the following should be done to remediate the slow speeds of the users?

choices.B: Run tracert from a desktop client to query each name server and see what answers are sent back from each server.
choices.C: Ping the name servers by IP address to make sure they are up, and then ping each name server by name in case name resolution is not working for the server names.
choices.A: Run a port scanner on each name server to ensure TCP port 53 is open and listening.
choices.D: Generate DNS queries and use a packet sniffer to capture DNS traffic to/from both name servers and look for differences.

discussion.content: "Both servers respond to queries made at the console." <--- Key thing. They respond to console.. but we need to ping them. Given answer is correct, C.

comments.content: I certainly do not understand.. B and D makes more sense to me -.-

Hmm. I can see how that would make C the answer. I just dont like the fact that the question says "he servers are both up and running" but then C says "Ping the name servers by IP address to make sure they are up" when the question literally already tells us that the servers are up...

questions.question_text: A system administrator reports that one of the two domain name servers does not seem to be responding to DNS requests from clients. The servers are both up and running, name service is running on them, and DNS requests appear in the logs. Both servers respond to queries made at the console. Which of the following tools should the systems administrator use to gather more information?

When trying to determine why users are unable to access a web-based application that was working the previous day, which of the following should be the FIRST question to ask to determine the scope of the issue?

discussion.content: A regular end user will not know if there was a change on the web server, finding out if another user or multiple users are experiencing the same issue would be much more ideal, so I personally am going with answer D

comments.content: agreed, although comptia doesnt care about what we think

discussion.content:
the Correct answer is A
Identify the problem
â€¢ Information gathering, identify symptoms,
question users, Check Change management documents
Hmm, I went with D as well but it says "why users are unable to access" indicating that perhaps it has been already established it is a wider issue. D says "a certain user's".

Personally, I think the question refers to what a technician would ask himself/herself before attempting to investigate and remediate the issue. Therefore, (A) is the most credible answer. Generally speaking, the end-users are not going to know the difference, only that a web app is no longer available, etc.
If the given answer is correct, the question may not be referring asking the user. It maybe referring to asking himself or other Techs maybe, IDK. I'm trying to make sense of this answer.

choices.D: Is this a system-wide issue or just a certain user's issue?
choices.C: Does the user have access to the application?
choices.A: What has been changed on the web server since the previous day?
choices.B: Is the application online for the end user to access?

questions.question_text: A technician recently ran a new cable over fluorescent lighting. Assuming the technician used the appropriate cables, which of the following connectors should be used to terminate it?

discussion.content:
Hello, My opinion is in the KEY words: 
over fluorescent lighting.
We use LC connector for optical cable that is meaning NO EMI. :)

Only cables immune to EMI is Optic fibre.
Only B made sense here
then again, who runs fibre cables over fluorescent lighting???

the "Comptia" logic, even though you could run any of these cables in theory (RJ11 being a telephone cable, so incorrect) neither of those two copper-type options indicate that they would protect from EMI, even if somehow they have got additional shielding or additional shielding could be possible. They ONLY one that would be immune is the optical cable option LC.
assuming the tech used the appropriate cables. Any copper cables would be subject to EMI. So it has to be fiber. LC (local connector) is a fiber connector type
why is it B? the question doesn't really specify what type of cable is being used nor what is it being used for?

comments.content: Fluorescent lighting gives off EMI to coaxial and ethernet cables, but not to fiber. You'd run fiber to prevent EMI, since it's immune to it.

questions.question_text:
A technician is troubleshooting a host that is having intermittent issues connecting to internal network resources and the company servers. Using a packet sniffer, the technician notices there are several TCP communications that are missing packets in sequence and need to be retransmitted. The technician receives several
SYN-ACK packets with incorrect addressing. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of these issues?

choices.D: Misconfigured VLAN on the local switch
choices.B: Evil twin on the company network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
the host is receiving SYN-ACK packets with incorrect addressing. This is more indicative of a routing issue, such as a misconfigured VLAN, rather than an ARP poisoning attack. ARP poisoning would not typically cause TCP communications to miss packets in sequence and need to be retransmitted, nor would it cause SYN-ACK packets to be sent to incorrect addresses.
Can someone provide info on why this is the right answer? This sounds like a TCP SYN Flood, not sure it is ARP Poisoning. The other 3 attacks also I don't think relate to this, could it be D?
